body:
Thanks @Lovkush-A, there are two related issues:
* for the explanation part, the user guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/361 
* the developer guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/464

> * for the explanation part, the user guide: [[DOC] User guideÂ #361](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/361)

Oh yes, I have seen this before. Contains my [first ever message and interaction with sktime](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/361#issuecomment-751351337). A real blast from the past!
also, questions should go into the discussions forum now

>If yes, then I think the current tutorials will need to be separated out into the 'tutorial' part and the 'explanation' part. Do people agree or disagree?

I think the format "code and explanation mixed" works reasonably well? Not sure what the alternative would look like though. Any good examples?

>What are the specific known weaknesses in the current documentation? What is it that people want to be better?

I think the main weakness is that many parts of it don't exist.

> I think the format "code and explanation mixed" works reasonably well?

Divio provide what I think are convincing arguments in favour of a different style of tutorial: https://documentation.divio.com/tutorials/. In particular, having less explanation and having more tasks for the user to do (so they get sense of achievement and also so they are more likely to learn how to use it for themselves).

One thing I like about divio's framework overall is that it is clearer where to look for different kinds of documentation. If I want to learn the absolute basics of how to use sktime, I go to a tutorial. If I want to know how to do a specific task in sktime (e.g. create a pipeline), I go to how-to guides. If I want to look for explanations, I go to some kind of explanations section.

Note, I do like the Forecasting and Classification tutorial notebooks, but I think they are better for 'explanations' rather than 'tutorials'.

> Not sure what the alternative would look like though. Any good examples?

Good question. I do not know examples. I can't say I have seen that many packages' documentation.

Lastly, I should say I am not strongly attached to divio's framework, but I think it is important we have some kind of framework, long-term plan and guiding principles.

>Divio provide what I think are convincing arguments in favour of a different style of tutorial: https://documentation.divio.com/tutorials/. In particular, having less explanation and having more tasks for the user to do (so they get sense of achievement and also so they are more likely to learn how to use it for themselves).

I think this sounds like a different kind of tutorial - self-work exercises.
It might be a good idea to have them, but I still think the user primarily expects the kind of "show and run" tutorial that they are familiar with for `sklearn` etc. I've seen exercises (e.g., in `pandas` docs) style tutorials, but that's always *in addition* to exercise style ones.

>Lastly, I should say I am not strongly attached to divio's framework, but I think it is important we have some kind of framework, long-term plan and guiding principles.

Sure - my proposal for immediate steps would be:

* replicate forecasting tutorial for other tasks
* add transformer tutorial
* write key missing doc page: tasks overview page
* write key missing doc page: general extension guideline (can take section from forecasting)
* write key missing doc pages: scientific reference pages (tasks etc)
* re-factor readme page with more direct links and info

> Sure - my proposal for immediate steps would be:

My proposal is to take a step back and determine how our documentaiton should look. E.g. in my view, there is overlap between the aim of the user guides and the current tutorial notebooks. All the steps you listed are sensible, but it would be good to know that they are fitting together to form a coherent set of documentation.

(Also, maybe I am overthinking things and we should jsut write some docs and worry about organising things nicely later)

Been skimmg through some of Ted Kaminski's essays on software engineering, and there is one on documentation: https://www.tedinski.com/2018/04/17/documentation-as-design-tool.html

For Ted, four important categories of documentation are:

* Good error messages! Never forget these count as documentation, too.
* Reference. This is the JavaDoc-style description of each individual exposed piece of an API.
* Explanatory/Concepts/Topics. There are frequently unifying ideas that are a part of an API which have no explicit code component, these needs documentation too.
* Examples. Sometimes this gets split up into âtutorials / how-to / guides,â but the idea is simple enough: give people code. Samples. Both introductory and more involved. If someone is asking a Stack Overflow question about your API and the best answer doesnât involve linking to code in your documentation, you may have something missing in this department.

Interesting to see overlap and differences with divio framework.

issue.title: [DOC] Update Documentation Content

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Describe the issue linked to the documentation

There are several sections of the documentation that can be updated, integrated or otherwise changed. Running list below. 

The goal of this Issue is to keep track of the potential changes. 

- [X] Add initial glossary
- [x] Improve estimator overview
- [ ] Get Started examples for other learning tasks
- [ ] Improve Related Software (soft dependency table at the top, add column for "learning task"/"focus area"/"Category", see #1183)
- [ ] Add missing modules to API References (e.g. clustering)
- [X] Add thumbnails for Get Involved page (see e.g. https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/) and other pages with a relatively small number of items in table of contents
- [x] Add more info to Enhancement Proposals page (ideally reusing README from the repo)
- [x] Add table for core devs, CC members, CoC members and interns/mentees to Contributor page
- [x] Add reviewer guide 
- [X] Add events page with embedded Google calendar or link to it
- [x] Add page for community contributions/links for blogs posts, applications, etc.
- [x] Convert markdown files in about folder to .rst

issue.title: [DOC] Rework tutorials

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Describe the issue linked to the documentation
* Notebooks are hard to maintain and improve iteratively using version control and GitHub
* Notebooks carry output which shouldn't be on git/GitHub 

#### Suggest a potential alternative/fix
In line with discussions on #1059:
* keep some of the notebooks as Jupyter notebooks for learning-oriented tutorials without the output and only efficient estimators which can be run when we generate the docs, focusing on workflow and key data science aspects, but not particular algorithms  
* convert other notebooks to Python files for problem-oriented how-to guides (e.g. how to use the ROCKET)

issue.title: [DOC] data container conventions, conversions, and data sets documentation

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Pull request on data container conventions and related functionality.

This is based on, and branching off the state of #1225 - and requests of @mloning and @TonyBagnall to document this.

The increment in this PR is the notebook `examples/00_datatypes.ipynb` which is supposed to explain:
* the different core in-memory data container datatypes for series and panels used in `sktime`, with examples to play around with
* validity checking, conversion, register, and type functionality
* data sets loading functionality

Ready for review
